Similarly, duplex 11 ultrasonography (DUS) for the diagnosis of DVT is difficult to perform due to large number of 12 patients, many of whom will be housed in field hospitals without diagnostic vascular unit labs 13 (DVUs), a contracted registered vascular technician workforce, and length of time associated 14 with and difficulty in completely disinfecting the machines in between patients. 15 Beyond the obligation of "do no harm" to our patient population, a global pandemic also 16 shines light on the moral obligations of and to ancillary healthcare staff. For instance, while it is 17 hotly debated on a national stage whether the physician "duty to treat" moral standard should be 18 upheld without proper personal protective equipment, it is even less clear to what obligation the 19 registered vascular technician (RVTs) should be held to when their services only indirectly 20 impact morbidity and mortality. It is arguably both within the realm of physician capability and 21 obligation to minimize exposure to RVTs in our DVUs, while minimizing harm to patients.

Furthermore, with a dedicated skill set requiring the use of expensive equipment, RVTs represent a scare resource during a pandemic, that if depleted, would inhibit our ability to detect other life 1 and limb threatening conditions that require urgent/emergent treatment such as acute limb 2 ischemia, pseudoaneurysms and carotid disease leading to stroke.

Facing mounting requests for duplex ultrasonography (DVT scans) for VTE diagnosis 4 during the exponential growth phase of the COVID-19 pandemic in our community, we formed 5 an ad hoc committee of venous thrombosis experts, vascular surgeons, hospitalists and critical 6 care physicians, vascular medicine physicians and RVTs. This committee is charged with rapidly 7 reviewing evidence for VTE diagnosis and treatment and adapt clinical algorithms for use during 8 a time when imaging resources, such as ultrasound machines and sonographers with experience 9 and expertise, are expected to be scarce, recognizing both our moral obligation to our patients 10 and to our vascular sonographers. Underlying these algorithms is the absolute commitment at 11 the institutional level to ensure appropriate diagnostic imaging, long term therapy 12 recommendations and follow up once the surge has passed. As a frame of reference, we are 13 expected to experience a volume of >3,000 patients at our peak in Michigan, and to be several 14 fold in excess of our hospital capacity, utilizing field hospitals for approximately 8 weeks. and critical care was solicited. Implementation was rapidly achieved via dissemination in care 4 bundles, computerized physician order entry (CPOE) sets, and best practice alerts.

Consensus was achieved regarding 9 critical guiding principles (Table I) based upon best 8 evidence, available resources and ethical obligations to patients and staff. High priority was 9 placed on treating suspected VTE without definitive imaging in the context of acceptable 10 bleeding risk, recognizing the potential to decrease morbidity and mortality. Extreme 11 pragmatism was applied, recognizing the well-being and scarcity of RVTs was paramount over 12 obtaining a diagnosis when clinical management would not be altered.

As an institutional standard, all patients are routinely risk assessed with the Caprini risk 15 assessment model upon admission. 2 The committee recognized that healthy patients with only a 16 diagnosis may fall into a low risk category that would not warrant VTE prophylaxis. There is a 17 paucity of data on VTE in COVID-19, however one study found a mortality benefit to 18 thromboprophylaxis with subcutaneous unfractionated heparin or low molecular weight heparin 19 amongst COVID-19 positive patients with highly elevated (>3x upper limit of normal) D-dimer 20 and sepsis induced coagulopathy score. 3 The true incidence of VTE is unknown, and likely 21 variable across different patient populations, with the highest case reports of pulmonary 22 embolism (PE) in up to 40% of patients with elevated D dimer undergoing CT PE. 4-6 These data suggest VTE or primary pulmonary thrombi may be an underlying etiology responsible for 1 mortality in severe COVID-19 infections. In patients who initially present with less severe 2 disease, the risk from failure to reassess and provide timely thromboprophylaxis in an over-3 capacity healthcare system is much more likely to outweigh the risk of major bleeding from 4 appropriately dosed thromboprophylaxis (~1%). 1 Further, while some may choose to use larger 5 doses of thromboprophylaxis, there is no clear evidence basis for this, and we defer to the front 6 line practicioner. 7 The committee therefore recommends routine thromboprophylaxis of all 7 hospitalized patients with COVID-19 regardless of risk score (Table II) . If the pre-test probability of the modified Wells' PE score is low (score ≤4, mean probably 12 of PE 1.7-2.2% if D-dimer negative; 5.1-7.8% overall, independent of the D-dimer): The 13 current recommendation is thromboprophylaxis for the non-intubated, admitted patient and the 14 intubated critically ill patient at high risk for bleeding (Figures 1 and 2) . The intubated, 15 critically ill patient who is low risk by the Wells' score may qualify for empiric lower dose 16 anticoagulation if their bleeding risk is low. Higher consideration should be given to empiric 17 low dose anticoagulation if the Partial pressure of arterial oxygen/Fractional inspired oxygen 18 (P/F) ratio is less than 200. We do not recommend that duplex ultrasonography be performed in 19 patients to exclude the diagnosis of PE. The rationale for this is that the use of DVT imaging in 20 the setting of suspected PE has a low accuracy, a sensitivity of 44%, a specificity of 86%, a 21 positive predictive value 58% and a negative predictive value of 77%. 9 This data has been 22 substantiated in other studies with reported sensitivities of 25-38% for the diagnosis of thrombosis when being used as a surrogate for PE. Thus, duplex imaging has significant 1 limitations in the diagnosis of PE or in situ pulmonary thrombosis and is not a direct test for PE.

A negative D dimer in combination with a low modified Wells' score is generally sufficient to 3 exclude PE as a diagnosis. However, in the setting of COVID-19 infection, which is associated 4 with elevated D dimer, the clinical utility of D dimer is unknown. 10 A clinician may draw a D 5 dimer at their discretion in the setting of a low modified Wells' score if a negative result will 6 reassure the patient. However, if positive, which is likely, it may distract from pursuing other, 7 more likely diagnoses.

If the pre-test probability is of the Wells' PE score is high (score >4): We recommend full 9 dose anticoagulation for the high risk patient with a low risk for bleeding anticoagulation based 10 on bleeding risk (VTE Bleed score <2, no other risk factors such as thrombocytopenia, cirrhosis, 11 other thrombotic use). Lower dose empiric anticoagulation may be utilized as clinically 12 appropriate in the intubated critically ill patients due to the bleeding risk associated with 13 hemorrhagic pneumonitis with higher Xa levels. For the patient at high risk of bleeding (Table   14 IV), the clinician could consider obtaining a CT PE study, if this would alter management. If a 15 CT PE is unable to be obtained, lower extremity duplex ultrasonography would be an alternative 16 option, recognizing limitations in sensitivity and specificity. Prior to obtaining imaging, 17 clinicians should screen each patient to ensure that testing will not be futile nor redundant (Table   18   V) . 19 If the diagnostic study is negative, thromboprophylaxis is recommended. If the study is positive, 20 consideration should be given to full dose anticoagulation in the non-intubated admitted patient 21 and lower dose empiric anticoagulation (either clinician run non-nomogram; or using the ACS 22 nomogram without bolus, Figures 1 and 2) in the intubated critically ill patients due to the bleeding risk, or full dose anticoagulation if felt to be appropriate by the intensivist. The existing Michigan Medicine faculty practice guidelines recommend utilization of Wells' 20 score to determine pretest probability of a DVT (Table VI) . 12 We recommend use of this score (Figures 3 and 4) . In the 19 high bleeding risk patient (VTE-BLEED score >2), a lower extremity DVT scan may be 20 indicated if the patients meets criteria (Table V) . We note that the VTE-BLEED score (Table   21 IV) is validated in the outpatient population, and that no similar score exists for use in the 22 acutely hospitalized nor critically ill population. This specific patient cohort may have additional risk factors that increase bleeding risk such as thrombocytopenia, cirrhosis and other anti-1 thrombotic use that should be taken into consideration by the clinician at the bedside. In patients who are treated with anticoagulants and are unable to get diagnostic imaging during 18 the COVID-19 surge, we recommend that they be discharged with a one to two-month supply of It is said that necessity is the mother of innovation. Just a few short months ago, it was 7 inconceivable that hospitals across the United States and the globe would be stretched far beyond 8 capacity, that essential resources would be rationed, and that even the most mundane, everyday 9 clinical diagnosis and treatment algorithms would be altered. This is the current status as only a 10 small aliquot of hours stand between us and the overwhelming tide of patients throughout the In this treatment paradigm, we emphasize preventing VTE related morbidity and mortality at the 1 expense of bleeding complications over a short term while imaging is delayed, and also utilizing 2 therapy that has shown benefit for other severe viral states (H1N1). While direct oral 3 anticoagulants are now more readily available, and have improved bleeding profile, we expect 4 that with such a large influx of patients, bleeding complications are a statistical certainty. With 5 such an approach, the commitment to providing follow up -the DVT scan that would normally 6 be obtained in 24 hours, now will be obtained in 2-4 weeks -must be absolute, meticulous and 7 unwavering.

The lack of hospital system beds across the country alongside the press reports of 9 temporary morgues and ventilator rationing may very well serve to undermine the confidence of 10 Americans in the existing healthcare infrastructure. Using content experts and protocolizing 11 treatment plans is one method that can allow us to maintain consistency in care delivery and Table I . Critical Guiding Principles 1. All patients with COVID-19 or suspected COVID-19 should be treated with thromboprophylaxis. This statement places value on avoiding the need to reassess VTE risk when a patient has a change in status, and accepts overall low bleeding risk associated with use of anticoagulants used at thromboprophylactic doses. 2. Elevated D-dimer is expected with severe COVID infection and should not be a determinant in the decision to obtain imaging. Negative D-dimer in combination with a low clinical risk score can still safely exclude VTE and may have limited utility for this purpose. 3. Current guidelines recommend empiric treatment of suspected PE if imaging is expected to take > 4 hours, or for DVT if imaging is expected to take > 24 hours. We expect that due to stress on the healthcare system that imaging may be delayed for up to a month or greater, but that patients may be safely empirically treated during this time by determining risk-benefit ratio. 4. Duplex ultrasonography should be utilized when the three following conditions are met simultaneously: (1) bleeding risk is high, (2) the results will change management (3) clinical suspicion of pulmonary embolism is high and CT PE is unobtainable or clinical suspicion of DVT is high (based upon modified Wells and Wells scoring systems). 5. Most patients with confirmed or suspected VTE who are not at high bleeding risk should receive therapeutic doses of anticoagulation. 6. In patients with ARDS, low dose non-nomogram heparin infusion may reduce risk of major bleeding while still protecting from thrombotic events. There is no data available for this treatment strategy in intubated patients without ARDS. 7. Patients treated with low dose anticoagulation protocols should be transitioned to full dose anticoagulation when no longer ICU status. 8. Referral for CT PE or duplex may be performed once patient has recovered as an inpatient, however, may need to be completed in the outpatient setting in a resource scarce setting. CVC venous clinics (or hematology, if a consulting service as inpatient) will provide continuity of care in reviewing these outpatient imaging tests and providing long term anticoagulation recommendations to the patient, thereby expediting discharges without the burden of additional testing and relieving inpatient providers of burden of follow up. 9. Upper extremity duplex ultrasonography should be limited to patients with unilateral limb symptoms and criteria as listed in #4 and should not be performed routinely. Introduction 2 The diagnosis of venous thromboembolism (VTE) traditionally relies upon assessment of 3 the patient for history and physical exam findings consistent with the diagnosis, risk 4 stratification, then imaging with duplex ultrasonography for deep venous thrombosis (DVT) or 5 with computed tomography (CT-PE) for pulmonary embolism. 1 This common diagnosis and its 6 work up are a familiar thread in the fabric of all emergency departments, inpatient wards and 7 intensive care units across the country and the world. FIGREF4.text: Rationale for using anticoagulation at lower than full dose but higher than prophylactic2 dose in those patients with severe ARDS: 3 Viral pneumonia associated venous thrombotic events resulting in significant mortality were 4 witnessed during the H1N1 2009 pandemic. Patients meeting the following criteria during this 5 time were treated with an empiric low dose anticoagulation protocol: P/F ratio < 200; viral 6 pneumonia suspected or confirmed; no absolute contraindications to anticoagulation. In patients 7 meeting these criteria, the following protocol reduced the risk of VTE and primary pulmonary 8 thrombi without increasing bleeding complications: initiation of non-nomogram heparin infusion 9 with a goal Xa between 0.2-0.3; no bolus dose administered. The lower Xa is necessary given 10 the risk of bleeding with hemorrhagic pneumonitis. Of note, this goal Xa does not match with an 11 existing heparin nomogram at our institution, and requires manual titration by the inpatient 12 team. 11 It therefore may be a reasonable, although untested, strategy to utilize the ACS 13 nomogram with lower Xa ranges (0.2-0.5) to reduce clinician workload if bleeding risk is 14 acceptable(Table II). In intubated patients without ARDS, there is a paucity of data regarding 15 risk-benefit ratio of empiric anticoagulation strategies. Patients with thrombocytopenia (platelets 16 < 30) should not be anticoagulated due to attendant bleeding risk, based on expert consensus.

Proactive use of an algorithmic approach to care in this 12 setting has the following advantages: (1) decreases variability in care across the healthcare13 system; (2) relieves stress on the individual provider on determining optimal treatment without 14 appropriate and usual diagnostic tests; (3) harnesses existing healthcare infrastructure to ensure 15 conscientious follow up for patients and restore confidence in the system; (4) protects scare 16 resources; and (5) fulfills our moral obligation to our patients and staff. 17 As we move forward through the inevitable crush of patients, conserving clinicians' 18 mental energy for critical decisions should be of the highest priority given the expected 19 emotional and mental exhaustion in the pandemic setting. As vascular specialists, using our 20 knowledge of clinical scoring systems and risk-benefit ratio, we can extrapolate the current 21 knowledge and standard of care to provide practical and pragmatic straightforward rules for 22 treatment that alleviates the bedside clinician mired in the purgatory of diagnostic uncertainty.

Undoubtedly, there are areas beyond VTE where 13 vascular surgeons can and are developing protocols that can help to streamline the care of 14 patients during a time of crisis. During the time of crisis, we can further respond by collating 15 data in an organized fashion, adapting protocols as more is learned and disseminating 16 information rapidly. Vascular surgeons are often the quarterback in crisis; but in the current 17 challenge of the COVID-19 pandemic our role is to use our expertise and tools to protect and aid 18 those serving on the frontlines.

TABREF0.text: Methods17A committee comprised of vascular thrombosis experts, vascular surgeons, vascular medicine 18 physicians, and vascular technologist was convened. We also sought, via multiple conference calls, input from intensivists, pulmonologists, and hematologists for critique and vetting of the algorithms that resulted. Existing published protocols for diagnosis and management of VTE by our faculty practice group were reviewed, alongside current ACCP and National Institution for Health and Care Excellence. 1 Our institutional experience with VTE events and utility of empiric low dose anticoagulation with H1N1 viral pneumonia were reviewed, as well as emerging evidence regarding VTE risk in COVID-19 infections. Feedback from content experts in vascular surgery, hematology, pharmacology, internal medicine, cardiology, anesthesiology
